discussion.p: Original title was: exponential_distribution<float> sometimes returns inf.
The random number distribution class template exponential_distribution<float> may return "inf" as can be seen from the following example program:
output:
The reason seems to be that converting a double x in the range [0, 1) to float may result in 1.0f if x is close enough to 1. I see two possibilities to fix that:

li.p: use internally double (or long double?) and then convert the result at the very end to float.
take only 24 random bits and convert them to a float x in the range [0, 1) and then return -log(1 - x).

discussion.p: I have not checked if std::exponential_distribution<double> has the same problem: For float on the average 1 out of 224 (~107) draws returns "inf", which is easily confirmed. For double on the average 1 out of 253 (~1016) draws might return "inf", which I have not tested.

Marshall:
I don't think the problem is in std::exponential_distribution; but rather in generate_canonical.
Options:

ul.li: 1) NAD, make it work. E.g. nudge slightly, making the hightest result return the highest allowable value (next_after). This might change the distribution slightly.
2) Re-run the algorithm when you get a 1. This changes the specification in that it makes extra calls to the random engine.

discussion.p: WEB: The one thing we cannot tolerate is any output range other than [0, 1).
WEB: I believe there may be a documented algorithm for the generator, and perhaps it's possible to discover en-route that the algorithm produces the wrong result and fix it.
MC: No. I analyzed this once, and here it is: the algorithm is in [rand.util.canonical], and it's all fine until p5. The expression S/R^k is mathematically less than one, but it may round to one.
GR: Could we change the rounding mode for the computation?
HH: No, because the rounding mode is global, not thread-local.
AM: SG1 wants to get rid of the floating point environment.
STL: The problem is that the standard specifies the implementation, and the implementation doesn't work.
MC: I'm not sure if nudging it down will introduce a subtle bias.
EF: I worry about how the user's choice of floating point environment affects the behaviour.
MS offers to run the topic past colleagues.
MC: Will set the status to open. STL wants to rename the issue. WEB wants to be able to find the issue by its original name still.
Mike Spertus to run the options past his mathematical colleagues, and report back.
Choice: Rerun the algorithm if it gets 1.0.
Thomas K to provide wording; Marshall and STL to review.

blockquote.p:
[…]
I am writing to report that I've recently cultivated a new source of random number expertise, and requested their careful review of that proposal. They have reported to me that the proposed resolution has satisfactory randomness characteristics.
They also point out, however, that the resolution incurs a not inconsiderable performance penalty.
If LWG is okay with that trade-off, I am prepared to support the proposal.

discussion.p:
Daniel:
Walter Brown refers here to this informal proposal suggested by Thomas Köppe at the 2017 Albuquerque meeting. The Proposed Wording part of that proposal is provided below as "Proposed resolution".

resolution.p: This wording is relative to N4713.

blockquote.pre: template<class RealType, size_t bits, class URBG> RealType generate_canonical(URBG& g);

blockquote.p:
-3- Complexity: For each attempt (see below), eExactly k = max(1, ⌈b/log2 R⌉) invocations of g, where b(footnote 276) is the lesser of numeric_limits<RealType>::digits and bits and log2(numeric_limits<RealType>::radix) × numeric_limits<RealType>::digits, and R is the value of g.max() - g.min() + 1.
-4- Effects: For each attempt, iInvokes g() k times to obtain values g0,…, gk-1, respectively and c. Calculates a quantity

S =
∑ i=0 k-1
( gi-g.min() ) · Ri
using arithmetic of type RealType. Attempts are repeated as long as the quantity S/Rk has the value 1.0 when expressed as type RealType.
-5- Returns: S/Rk.
-6- Throws: What and when g throws.
